Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Consortium for Undergraduate Research Experiences (CURE)
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides renewed funding for the Consortium for Undergraduate Research Experiences (CURE), which is a collaboration between six Los Angeles-area community colleges and NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory (JPL). Fifty-five percent of all California State University students, and nearly one third of all University of California students, start their careers in community colleges, and yet these students may never have access to top-notch research and mentoring opportunities while at their local colleges. CURE's mission is to provide these students -- especially females, underrepresented minorities, non-traditional students -- this cutting-edge access. Students will be paired with JPL scientists to conduct research at both JPL and its Table Mountain Observatory. They will perform detailed research into a variety of topics, including space physics instrumentation, observations and analysis of asteroids, and spectroscopy of minerals likely to be found on Mars.

By offering high-quality research experiences and dedicated mentoring to students in partnership with one of the world's most prolific space science institutions, CURE aims to propel its participants to transfer successfully to four-year universities and advanced degree programs and careers in STEM fields. Its previous award (AST-1156756) is an exemplar of success: many students have published their research, and almost all have transferred to four-year universities. This new award will enable CURE to place a renewed focus on boosting the numbers of females and African American in the program, which will expand STEM training opportunities to these groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
CURE is an REU site that provides high-level, substantive Astronomy-related research internships for underserved, non-traditional, and minority Los Angeles-area community college students at NASA/Caltech's Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena, Ca (and affiliated research sites), with the intent of guiding students to transfer to four-year universities, get their four-year degree, and continue on to graduate school and careers in STEM fields.  The program specifically targets underserved students in the LA area women, minorities, veterans, and "second chance" older students.

CURE's primary goal is to provide students who otherwise would not have access to high-level internships the opportunity to see a path for themselves to a research career in science, and especially astronomy and physics.  CURE students come from diverse backgrounds (including first-generation college students) and being from community colleges, they would not otherwise have the opportunities for research that CURE provides.  CURE inspires them and provides them with a pathway to careers in astronomy, physics and engineering.  Brining them into CURE is a dream come true for both them and their families.  CURE shows them, and society in general in a very real way, that NO ONE is shut out of participating in real science in our society, no matter what their background, experience or origin.

CURE's impact is as much social as it is scientific.  Most CURE interns are usually first-generation college students, minority, female or other underserved students, often with very little means.  The interns' families are sometimes as much a part of the program as the students are, sacrificing to get the students a car for transportation for example, or a computer to work on.  CURE is a program that prepares students and their families, who would otherwise not be part of the academic world, to launch themselves into this new experience that will hopefully transform their lives in a way that they could not possibly have hoped for.  One of the most frequent comments we get about CURE from the students is "I didn't think this kind of experience was available to me."  Thanks to CURE, it is available, and the confidence it gives them, and the pride it instills in their families gives them the impetus to transfer to a four-year University and make it through the rigors of academia.  If it were not for CURE, these students would have no other experience like this, and perhaps most importantly, at least for first generation college or immigrant students, not other support system to guide them to the next step.

CURE students did real research.  Amongst other projects, they did important work classifying and measuring the properties and precise positions of asteroids and Near-Earth Objects, developed space instrumentation (for an ultra-compact magnetograph), developed an important on-line database where amateur astronomers can collect an share data with professional astronomers, developed procedures for studying ways to design future missions to icy Solar System moons, and wrote code to analyze dust disks around developing stars.  Many of these projects are extending knowledge into new, unmeasured areas.  For example, many of the asteroids studied by CURE students were previously unknown are only very recently discovered.  Many of the techniques (ultra-compact magnetograph and icy moon analysis techniques) are at the very edge of their fields in space and planetary exploration.  CURE students are not just "adding another decimal place," but pushing knowledge further and enabling the next generation of astronomy and planetary science to go forward.

Every one of the CURE students has transferred to a four-year University to continue their STEM studies.  We have students attending a variety of the UC campuses, including Berkeley, Santa Barbara, Irvine, Riverside, and Davis.  In addtion some students have chosen the CSU system, for instance transferring to CSULB, while others have chosen to attend private universities, such as USC.  These students count their CURE experience as highly rewarding and enjoyable.  By any metric, the CURE program has been a success!
